name: Hawaiʻi Volcanoes National Park
description: Hawai‘i Volcanoes National Park protects some of the most unique geological, biological, and cherished cultural landscapes in the world. Extending from sea level to 13,680 feet, the park encompasses the summits of two of the world's most active volcanoes - Kīlauea and Mauna Loa - and is a designated International Biosphere Reserve and UNESCO World Heritage Site.
shortDescription: Hawai‘i Volcanoes National Park protects some of the most unique geological, biological, and cherished cultural landscapes in the world. Extending from sea level to 13,680 feet, the park encompasses t...

operatingHours.description: Hawai‘i Volcanoes National Park is open 7 days a week, 24 hours a day including holidays.

fees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle
fees.description: Private Vehicle Pass - The private vehicle pass admits the passholder and up to 14 passengers of a single, private (non-commercial) vehicle.

fees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle
fees.description: Valid for 7 days. Admits up to 2 private, non-commercial motorcycles with up to 4 total passengers.

fees.title: Entrance - Per Person
fees.description: Pedestrian/Cyclist Pass - Admits one individual bicyclist, hiker, or pedestrian visiting without a private vehicle. An individual pass is not required for visitors aged 15 and under.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus
fees.description: The commercial entrance fee for a Road Based Guided Tour is based on vehicle seating capacity. For a 16-25 passenger vehicle the user fee is $100.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach
fees.description:
The commercial entrance fee for a Road Based Guided Tour is based on vehicle seating capacity. For a 26+ passenger vehicle the user fee is $200. 

Large vehicles, defined as more than 26 feet in length and/or more than eight feet wide, are only allowed to operate on Crater Rim Drive to Kilauea Visitor Center, Kūkamāhuākea (Steam Vents), and Uēkahuna. Mauna Loa Road to the Kīpukapuaulu turnabout.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Per Person
fees.description: $15 per person for Commercial Non-Road Based Guided Tours. This includes hiking more than one mile on one trail, bird watching on foot for more than one hour at one location, and/or or bicycling tours.

climate.weatherDescription: The weather the summit of Kīlauea (~4000' elevation) varies daily and may be rainy and chilly any time of the year. Temperature varies by elevation. At the summit of the volcano, temperatures may be 12 to 15 degrees cooler than at sea level. The coastal plain at the end of Chain of Craters Road is often hot, dry, and windy with the possibility of passing showers.

images.title: Halapē
images.altText: Rocky coastline with palm trees and a cliff beyon
images.caption: Coastline of Hawaiʻi Volcanoes National Park

images.title: Kīlauea Iki
images.altText: A cloud-filled volcanic crater at sunrise with a mountain rising behind
images.caption: Sunrise at Kīlauea Iki

images.title: Hōlei Pali
images.altText: Lava flows and ferns in front of a cliff at sunset
images.caption: Lava flows from the Mauna Ulu eruption drape the Hōlei Pali

images.title: Steam Vents
images.altText: Trees and tall grass through steam at sunrise
images.caption: Wahinekapu (Steaming Bluff)

images.title: The Kahuku Unit
images.altText: Grassy hill dotted with trees underneath a blue sky with white clouds
images.caption: The Kahuku Unit of Hawaiʻi Volcanoes National Park once was one of the largest cattle ranches in Hawaiʻi

images.title: Tide Pools
images.altText: Green vegetation in tide pools on a rocky ocean coastline
images.caption: Tide pools along the Puna Coast

images.title: Nāhuku
images.altText: A lava tube lit by warm electric light
images.caption: Nāhuku (Thurston Lava Tube)

images.title: Lava Trees
images.altText: A lava tree in a black lava field with small living trees and a rainbow behind
images.caption: Lava trees memorialize trees that once stood in the path of encroaching lava

images.title: ʻAe Fern
images.altText: Ferns rising from a lava field
images.caption: About 200 species of ferns can be found across the Hawaiian Islands. Sixty-five percent of these species are considered endemic, found nowhere else in the world.

images.title: ʻŌhiʻa
images.caption: The red blossoms of the ʻōhiʻa are a Hawaiian cultural icon
